name: Arcadia
keyboard: Two detachable controllers made of a screwable joystick, a 12-buttons keypad (0-9, CLEAR, ENTER) and two fire buttons (same function)
rom: None in the conventional sense, though there was some built into the processor chips.
description:
The Bandai Arcadia, is the same system as the Emerson Arcadia 2001, but sold in Japan. Please see this entry for more detailed informations.

The Arcadia 2001 clones includes : Advision Home Arcade (France), Bandai  Arcadia (Japan), GiG Electronics Leonardo (Italy), Hanimex HMG-2650, Leisure-Dynamics Leisure-Vision, Intercord XL 2000 system, Eduscho / Tchibo Tele-Fever, etc... It means that all these systems can directly use the same cartridges.

The Software library is not very impressive, but there are good reasons for that. First, some titles ar almost just direct ports from "Interton VC-4000 & compatible systems" group. Philips (remember, at the origin of this ystem) also had great plans for his new hardware platform. It released adaptations of famous Arcade classics (Pac-Man, Berzerk, Phoenix, etc.) but Atari sue them. Philips was then forced to deeply modify those games, resulting in poor adaptations... at least for the Arcadia 2001. Because, outside US, other compatible systems sometimes had un-modified version in their library (Robot Killer for the MPT-03, for example).

The Arcadia is equiped with two detachable controllers made of a screwable joystick, a 12-buttons keypad (flat membrane buttons) and 2 fire buttons (they in fact have both the same function). Small plastic layers were delivered with each game, explaining the different key functions when placed over the keypads (like with the Mattel Intellisivision).

The Control panel is made of 4 buttons (Start, Clear, Select A and Select B) and the power on/off button.

advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (JAN. 1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"I met Apple IIc" <br><br> French advert from MAJUSCULE distributor.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1979)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br> <font color="#666666">You know about computers. In fact, you probably own one now. One that you might be thinking of expanding. We have a better idea. Take a giant step into the personal computing future with an amazing, new C4P from Ohio Scientific...<br><br> ...The C4P is an outstanding premium computer - years ahead of the market. We know because there's nothing quite like it for the price, anywhere. And probably won't be for a very long time.</font> <br><br> About the DISPLAY paragraph:<font color="#666666"><br> "256 x 512 effective graphic points"<br><br></font> <b>Kurt Vogel</b> rectifies:<font color="#666666"><br> The C4P did NOT have a 256x512 graphics mode!  If it had, that would have been amazing for the price way back then.  Instead, it had a 32x64 character display and claimed that because each character was made up of a 8x8 grid that that was supposed to count as 256x512 graphics.  Even given that they used an extended 8 bit character set that included special line and shape characters, you were NEVER able to address indivual pixels!</font>       </blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>New Brain complet package with FDD´s and peripherals... (the dot matrix printer was connected to the RS232 port)... The main box you see in the photo is the "school network controller" that permitted that "n" computers were plugged in as a network sharing one "5Mb hard drive"<p class="petitgris">Thanks to Rui Santos for this picture</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PREVIOUS SYSTEM</strong></font><br><blockquote>Before manufacturing the MPC, Columbia tried to sell a massive multi-user, Z80 based system.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote>The advert show the built-in user menu and system status.<br><br> The right located system is the dual-drive version.<br> The left one is the 10 MB hard-disk version.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT, OCT. 1981</strong></font><br><blockquote>From Personal Computing, October 1981.<p class="petitgris">Courtesy of '<a href="http://www.aci.com.pl/mwichary/" target="_blank">Attached</a>'</p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH BROCHURE BACK</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Oric opens a full world to you"<p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Jacques Sorro</b></p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> ACORN AD. #3 (NOV. 86)</strong></font><br><blockquote>Advert said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> The BBC Master Compact's educational software, takes children from their first grasp of words and numbers to A-level and beyond.<br> In 84% of U.K. schools, children are already growing up with BBC micros.<br> With a BBC Master Compact at home, your child's ability with computers will progress in leaps and bounds... </font></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (AUGUST 1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is an advert for the Yannick Noah Tennis cartridge. The game is only called "Grand Slam Tennis" on the Emerson Arcadia 2001, but in France was marketed with the most famous french tennis player's name, Yannick Noah.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> NEWBRAIN BROCHURE</strong></font><br><blockquote>The first Newbrain brochure only offered two models:<br><br> Model AD: with display<br> Model A:  without Display <p class="petitgris">Courtesy of <b>www.oldcomputers.freeserve.co.uk</b>   </p></blockquote>
